items.title: Black activists in NY duel over proposed bans on menthol cigarette sales
items.description: Some worry the bans will mean more encounters with cops. Others decry the flavored cigarettes' deadly toll on Black people.

image.title: shutterstock_editorial_13437417a.jpg DO NOT REUSE
image.caption: Menthol-flavored cigarettes would be banned under proposals pending in the State Legislature and New York City Council

items.title: Penn Station redevelopment isnâ€™t dead yet, Gov. Hochul says
items.description: On WNYC, the Democratic governor declined to give up on the Penn Station project, even though Vornado has paused its involvement.

image.title: Hochul Getty do not reuse
image.alt: Gov. Kathy Hochul speaks during a press event on Long Island.
image.caption: Gov. Kathy Hochul speaks during a press event on Long Island.
image.credit: Steve Pfost/Newsday RM via Getty Images

related_authors.biography: Jon Campbell covers the New York State Capitol for WNYC and Gothamist. Prior to that, he covered the Capitol for more than a decade for the USA TODAY Network. He has twice earned the Walter T. Brown Memorial Award, an honor given annually by the Legislative Correspondents Association alumni for outstanding state government coverage. Jon grew up in the Buffalo area and graduated from the University at Albany.

items.title: NYPD arrests man suspected of robbing 4 bodegas, killing 1
items.description: The NYPD announced the arrest of 39-year-old Kimond Cyrus, accusing him of robbing four bodegas in Brooklyn and Manhattan, killing an employee in the process.

image.title: shutterstock_60781090.jpg
image.alt: Police tape at a crime scene
image.caption: Police are investigating an incident in which a woman was killed by a hit-and-run driver early Saturday morning in Queens.

related_authors.biography: Isidoro Rodriguez reports on safety and policing in New York City. Prior to joining Gothamist, he was  deputy editor of The Crime Report at the Center on Media, Crime and Justice at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in New York.

items.title: Cost of 2nd Avenue Subway extension to East Harlem balloons to $7.7B
items.description: Itâ€™s the latest price hike for the project, which aims to extend the subway by 1.5 miles through a tunnel thatâ€™s already partially built.

related_authors.biography: Stephen Nessen covers transportation. Since 2008 he has reported on everything from Occupy Wall Street, the rebuilding of the World Trade Center site, Hurricane Sandy, to Trumpâ€™s campaign for president. His transportation reporting has taken him everywhere from the MTAâ€™s secret Rail Control Center to the gleaming subways of Seoul.

items.title: Extra Extra: Remember the time before legal weed, when NYC smelled awesome?
items.description: Because the scent of that dank kush is pushing some longtime New Yorkers over the edge, here are your end-of-day links: Undercover taxi boss, smoking inside Atlantic City casinos, COVID rats and more.

items.title: Gov. Hochul wants to loan $455 million to Belmont Park. Some say itâ€™s a bad bet.
items.description: If the loan goes through, the state would take control of more than 100 acres near JFK International Airport.

image.title: Belmont Park [Shutterstock]
image.alt: Mo Donegal, with Irad Ortiz Jr. wins The Belmont Stakes presented by NYRA Bets at Belmont Park in Elmont in June last year. Hochul seeks to issue a $455 million loan to Belmont Park to redevelop the grandstand and clubhouse.
image.caption: Mo Donegal, with Irad Ortiz Jr. wins the Belmont Stakes presented by NYRA Bets at Belmont Park in Elmont in June last year. Hochul seeks to issue a $455 million loan to Belmont Park to redevelop the grandstand and clubhouse.

related_authors.biography: Jon Campbell covers the New York State Capitol for WNYC and Gothamist. Prior to that, he covered the Capitol for more than a decade for the USA TODAY Network. He has twice earned the Walter T. Brown Memorial Award, an honor given annually by the Legislative Correspondents Association alumni for outstanding state government coverage. items.title: 250K NYC retirees must switch to new Medicare coverage after union leaders favor privatized plan

listing_image.title: medicare advantage vote_20230309_GettyImages-1246120531.jpg
listing_image.alt: Participants seen cheering during an NYC City Council hearing about the proposed changes to the cityâ€™s administrative code and municipal retirees' health care benefits, Jan. 9, 2023.
listing_image.caption: Participants seen cheering during an NYC City Council hearing about the proposed changes to the cityâ€™s administrative code and municipal retirees' health care benefits, Jan. 9, 2023.

items.description: The switch will provide some new benefits, but critics of the change have raised concerns that the Medicare Advantage plan will be more likely to require prior approval for certain medical services and potentially deny coverage.

image.title: medicare advantage_20230309_shutterstock_editorial_13740802a.jpg
image.alt: A page from the 2019 U.S. Medicare Handbook in Washington.
image.caption: According to a summary of the plan that was shared with Gothamist, Aetna wonâ€™t require prior authorization for any medical services for the first 120 days after coverage begins.

related_authors.biography: Caroline Lewis is on the health care beat for WNYC and Gothamist â€” and also covers cannabis, both with an eye towards equity and accountability. She was previously a health care reporter for Crainâ€™s New York Business. Lewis has a degree from the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism and is a native New Yorker, although she has left occasionally. She did a Fulbright in Chile in 2011 and is fluent in Spanish. She now resides in Brooklyn.

items.title: Daylight saving time is coming to NYC â€” beware
items.description: We're still changing the clocks twice a year even though most people think it's silly and scientists say it's dangerous.

image.title: DST GETTY NO REUSE .jpg
image.alt: A photo of a clock in springtime to depict daylight saving time.
image.caption: Yes, we'll have later sunsets, but scientists say daylight saving time messes with our sleep.

items.title: Toxic fumes detected at popular Brooklyn shuffleboard club for past 2 years
items.description: Hereâ€™s why youâ€™re only now hearing about the incident at the Royal Palms Shuffleboard Club.

image.title: royal palms_20230308_shuffleboard. gas_L1500214.jpeg
image.alt: The Royal Palms Shuffleboard Club is located at 514 Union Street in Brooklyn. Environmental surveys detected high levels of a cancer-causing chemical called trichloroethylene and other industrial pollutants at the site in early 2021. But state regulators took a year to notify nearby residents about the health hazard. Remediation efforts to contain the toxins began last month.
image.caption: The Royal Palms Shuffleboard Club is located at 514 Union Street in Brooklyn. Environmental surveys detected high levels of a cancer-causing chemical called trichloroethylene and other industrial pollutants at the site in early 2021. But state regulators took a year to notify nearby residents about the health hazard. Remediation efforts to contain the toxins began last month.
